body: I don't think we have anyone using that, so it may be up to you to debug it. I'd guess that there's something which stops the signal getting to IPython - in which case, there may not be much we can do about it.

Thank you for your answer, Thomas !

I understand it is a very specific case and I hesitated before reporting 
the issue.
Why I reported it:
- every other applications I launched with AutoHotKeys (relying on 
  cmd.exe or not) in the same context have
   no issue with Ctrl-C,
- it is easy to test: install AHK 
  (http://l.autohotkey.net/AutoHotkey_L_Install.exe), create a 
  test_IPython.ahk
  file and inside put the line hereafter, then launch the script:
  
  ```
   Run C:\Python27\python.exe "C:\Python27\scripts\ipython-script.py"
  ```

You will note Ctrl-C has no effect :-(

I guess this may have something to do with interact() method of class 
TerminalInteractiveShellinside
interactiveshell.py, where exists a "double-guard against keyboard 
interrupts during kbdint handling".

I tried many workarounds, including usage of alternate console solution 
(Console2), without change.

I think this issue report may reveal a very vicious bug.
It is up to you to decide to investigate or not (obviously). Keep in 
mind AutoHotKeys is a very mature soft
and the test case is very simple.

I thank you for any help.

Best regards,

Laurent

I'm closing this due to inactivity and the fact that this is a 3rd party program that's causing the issue. If @cemoi wanted to reopen this one, the way forward would be to check what happens to ctrl-c when running a plain Python.exe using AutoHotkey
